title: Problem Overview
content:
**Erdős Problem #140**: Density of 3-AP-Free Sets

**Question**: Prove r₃(N) ≪ N/(log N)^C for every C > 0.

**Status**: SOLVED (Kelley-Meka 2023)
**Prize**: $500

**Answer**: YES. The Kelley-Meka theorem proves this is the best possible bound of this form.

This represents a major breakthrough in additive combinatorics.
mathContext: r₃(N) is the maximum size of a subset of {1,...,N} with no 3-term arithmetic progression. The problem asks for near-optimal density bounds.

title: 3-Term Arithmetic Progressions
content:
**IsAP3 a b c**: 2b = a + c ∧ a < b < c

Three values a, a+d, a+2d form a 3-AP when d ≠ 0.

**Is3APFree A**: No three elements of A form a 3-AP.

**Finset3APFree A**: Same for finite sets.

Examples: {1,2,3} has a 3-AP. {1,2,4} is 3-AP-free.
mathContext: The condition 2b = a + c is equivalent to b - a = c - b, meaning b is the arithmetic mean of a and c.

title: The Roth Number r₃(N)
content:
**r3 N** = max{ |A| : A ⊆ {0,...,N}, A is 3-AP-free }

Defined as the supremum over all valid subsets.

**theorem r3_achieved** ✓: The supremum is achieved by some finite set.

**Proof**: The set of achievable cardinalities is nonempty (∅ works) and bounded by N+1, so the supremum exists and is achieved.
mathContext: This is Roth's original quantity. Understanding r₃(N) is central to additive combinatorics and Ramsey theory.

title: Roth's Theorem (1953)
content:
**axiom roth_theorem**: r₃(N) = o(N)

The first non-trivial upper bound showing 3-AP-free sets have density 0.

**Explicit bound**: r₃(N) ≤ C·N / log log N

Roth won the Fields Medal in part for this work.
mathContext: Roth used Fourier-analytic methods (circle method) to prove this. It showed that large 3-AP-free sets cannot exist.

title: Historical Progress
content:
**Bourgain (2008)**: r₃(N) = O(N / √(log log N))
Improved Roth using deeper Fourier analysis.

**Sanders (2011)**: r₃(N) = O(N (log log N)⁵ / log N)
First bound with log N in denominator!

**Bloom-Sisask (2020)**: r₃(N) = O(N / (log N)^{1+c}) for some c > 0
Breakthrough: power > 1 in log exponent.
mathContext: Each improvement required new techniques. Sanders introduced nilsequences; Bloom-Sisask used entropy-based methods.

title: Kelley-Meka Theorem (2023)
content:
**KelleyMekaTheorem**: ∀ C > 0, ∃ K > 0, ∀ N ≥ 3:
  r₃(N) ≤ K·N / (log N)^C

**axiom kelley_meka**: KelleyMekaTheorem

**theorem erdos_140_solved** = kelley_meka

This resolves Erdős Problem #140 and the $500 prize!
mathContext: Kelley-Meka's proof uses a novel approach combining spectral methods with graph theory. The paper appeared in 2023.

title: Corollaries
content:
**theorem r3_superlogarithmic**: For all C > 0, ε > 0:
  r₃(N) < ε·N / (log N)^C for large N

Apply Kelley-Meka with exponent C + 1.

**theorem r3_density_vanishes**: r₃(N)·(log N)^C / N → 0

The density vanishes faster than any inverse power of log N.
mathContext: These show Kelley-Meka is nearly optimal. The density cannot decay much faster due to Behrend's lower bound.

title: Behrend Lower Bound
content:
**axiom behrend_lower_bound**:
  r₃(N) ≥ N · exp(-c · √(log N))

This is the best known LOWER bound (1946).

**The Gap**:
- Upper: O(N / (log N)^C) for all C
- Lower: Ω(N / exp(c √log N))

The true order of r₃(N) remains unknown!
mathContext: Behrend constructed 3-AP-free sets in a d-dimensional sphere. The gap between bounds is a major open problem.

title: 3-AP-Free Examples (Verified)
content:
**example** ✓: {0} is 3-AP-free (trivially)

**example** ✓: {1, 2, 4, 5, 10, 11, 13, 14} is 3-AP-free

This is the first 8 elements of the greedy 3-AP-free sequence (OEIS A003278).

Verified by case analysis with omega tactic.
mathContext: The greedy sequence starts: 1, 2, 4, 5, 10, 11, 13, 14, 28, 29, ... It grows roughly like N^0.63.

title: Greedy 3-AP-Free Sequence
content:
**greedyAP3Free n**: The greedy sequence A003278

Start with 1, then repeatedly add the smallest integer that doesn't create a 3-AP.

Yields: 1, 2, 4, 5, 10, 11, 13, 14, 28, 29, ...

**axiom greedy_is_3APFree**: The greedy sequence is 3-AP-free.
mathContext: The greedy sequence has been studied extensively. Its growth rate is approximately n^(log 2 / log 3) ≈ n^0.63.

title: k-term AP Generalization
content:
**IsAPk k vals**: k values form an arithmetic progression
  vals(i) = a + i·d for some a, d with d ≠ 0

**FinsetkAPFree k A**: No k elements of A form a k-AP

**rk k N**: Maximum size of k-AP-free subset of {0,...,N}

**ErdosAPConjecture**: For all k ≥ 3, C > 0:
  r_k(N) = O(N / (log N)^C)

This is OPEN for k ≥ 4!
mathContext: Szemerédi's theorem (1975) shows r_k(N) = o(N), but the quantitative bounds are much weaker for k ≥ 4.

title: k=3 Case (Verified)
content:
**theorem r3_eq_rk_3** ✓: r₃ N = r_k 3 N

The Roth number definitions are equivalent.

**theorem erdos_ap_conjecture_k3** ✓:
For all C > 0, r_3(N) = O(N / (log N)^C)

Direct application of Kelley-Meka to the generalized definition.
mathContext: This shows Kelley-Meka resolves the k=3 case of Erdős's generalized conjecture. The k ≥ 4 cases remain open.

title: Summary and Status
content:
**Erdős Problem #140: SOLVED** (Kelley-Meka 2023)
**Prize: $500**

**Verified:**
- r3_achieved ✓
- Examples: {0}, {1,2,4,5,10,11,13,14} ✓
- r3_eq_rk_3 ✓
- erdos_ap_conjecture_k3 ✓

**Timeline:**
1953: Roth → 2008: Bourgain → 2011: Sanders → 2020: Bloom-Sisask → 2023: Kelley-Meka

**OPEN**: True order of r₃(N), and k ≥ 4 cases.
mathContext: The problem took 70 years from Roth's initial breakthrough to Kelley-Meka's resolution. The Behrend gap remains.
